articles.headline: Home Solar Is Growing, but Big Installers Are Still Losing Money
articles.snippet: Some companies are having trouble surviving and making money installing panels because of intense competition and the high costs of doing business.
articles.abstract: Some companies are having trouble surviving and making money installing panels because of intense competition and the high costs of doing business.
articles.lead_paragraph: The home solar business is growing fast as thousands of homeowners install panels on their roofs to save money. Yet the biggest companies that install and finance home solar systems are reporting hundreds of millions of dollars in losses.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Ivan Penn

articles.headline: In a Topsy-Turvy Pandemic World, China Offers Its Version of Freedom
articles.snippet: Surveillance and censorship bolster Beijing’s uncompromising grip on power. But in the country’s cities and streets, people have resumed normal lives.
articles.abstract: Surveillance and censorship bolster Beijing’s uncompromising grip on power. But in the country’s cities and streets, people have resumed normal lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Duncan Clark’s flight was rolling down the runway in Paris in late October when President Emmanuel Macron announced a second national lockdown in France. The country had nearly 50,000 new Covid-19 infections that day. The United States had almost 100,000.

articles.headline: $900 Billion Won’t Carry Biden Very Far
articles.snippet: Despite new pandemic aid, he confronts an economic crisis unlike any since he last entered office in 2009. And political headwinds have only stiffened.
articles.abstract: Despite new pandemic aid, he confronts an economic crisis unlike any since he last entered office in 2009. And political headwinds have only stiffened.
articles.lead_paragraph: With his presidential inauguration just weeks away, Joseph R. Biden Jr. is confronting an economic crisis that is utterly unparalleled and yet eerily familiar.

articles.headline: An Insurgency From Inside the Oval Office
articles.snippet: President Trump’s effort to overturn the election he lost has gone beyond mere venting of grievances at the risk of damaging the very American democracy he is charged with defending.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s effort to overturn the election he lost has gone beyond mere venting of grievances at the risk of damaging the very American democracy he is charged with defending.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s relentless effort to overturn the result of the election that he lost has become the most serious stress test of American democracy in generations, one led not by outside revolutionaries intent on bringing down the system but by the very leader charged with defending it.

articles.headline: Britain Re-enters Sweeping Lockdown as Virus Variant Rages
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Boris Johnson closed schools and declared a national lockdown in England, following on the heels of Scotland.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Boris Johnson closed schools and declared a national lockdown in England, following on the heels of Scotland.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson imposed a strict new national lockdown on Monday as Britain’s desperate race to vaccinate its population risked being overtaken by a fast-spreading variant of the coronavirus that was on track to overwhelm the nation’s beleaguered hospitals.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Amazon, Berkshire and JPMorgan Will End Joint Health Care Venture
articles.snippet: The company, Haven, had promised to disrupt the way large corporations deliver benefits to their employees.
articles.abstract: The company, Haven, had promised to disrupt the way large corporations deliver benefits to their employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: A joint venture formed by Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase to explore new ways to deliver health care to their employees is disbanding, according to a short statement on its website. The company, Haven, will cease operations at the end of February — three years after its arrival sent shock waves through the health care industry.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Karen Weise

articles.headline: Republicans, Fearing Trump’s Wrath, Splinter Over Bid to Overturn Election
articles.snippet: Facing a consequential test, Republicans staked out dueling positions over whether to join an insurgency in their ranks pushing to invalidate President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory
articles.abstract: Facing a consequential test, Republicans staked out dueling positions over whether to join an insurgency in their ranks pushing to invalidate President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican divisions deepened on Monday over an effort to overturn President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory, as lawmakers weighed their fear of alienating President Trump and his supporters against the consequences of voting to reject a democratic election.
articles.byline: By Catie Edmondson and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: As Georgians Prepare to Vote, Trump Interference Draws Rebuke
articles.snippet: A top election official condemned President Trump’s baseless attacks on voting integrity, as the president and Joe Biden rallied support for their candidates in the crucial Senate runoffs.
articles.abstract: A top election official condemned President Trump’s baseless attacks on voting integrity, as the president and Joe Biden rallied support for their candidates in the crucial Senate runoffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Here’s what you need to know about President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s Inauguration Day.]
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset, Rick Rojas and Maggie Astor

articles.headline: A Simple Way to End Questionable Stock Trading by Lawmakers
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission has broad powers that could be used to regulate trades by members of Congress, avoiding the need for legislation.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has broad powers that could be used to regulate trades by members of Congress, avoiding the need for legislation.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Senator Kelly Loeffler, Republican of Georgia, was investigated over insider trading claims last spring, along with at least three of her colleagues, she announced that she and her husband would no longer trade individual stocks; her family would divest them and move their money into diversified mutual funds.
